sentences.sentence: When the great moment came and the Beasts spoke, he missed the whole point; for a rather interesting reason.
When the Lion had first begun singing, long ago when it was still quite dark, he had realized that the noise was a song.
And he had disliked the song very much.
It made him think and feel things he did not want to think and feel.

Then, when the sun rose and he saw that the singer was a lion (“only a lion,” as he said to himself) he tried his hardest to make believe that it wasn’t singing and never had been singing—only roaring( 吼叫 ) as any lion might in a zoo in our own world.
“Of course it can’t really have been singing,” he thought, “I must have imagined it. I’ve been letting my nerves( 神经 ) get out of order. Who ever heard of a lion singing?”
And the longer and more beautiful the Lion sang, the harder Uncle Andrew tried to make himself believe that he could hear nothing but roaring( 吼叫声 ).
Now the trouble about trying to make yourself stupider than you really are is that you very often succeed. Uncle Andrew did.
He soon did hear nothing but roaring( 吼叫声 ) in Aslan’s song.
Soon he couldn’t have heard anything else even if he had wanted to.
And when at last the Lion spoke and said, “Narnia awake,” he didn’t hear any words: he only heard a snarl( 吼叫声 ).
And when the Beasts spoke in answer, he heard only barkings, growlings( 咆哮 ), bayings( 长嗥 ), and howlings( 嚎叫 ).
And when they laughed—well, you can imagine.
That was worse for Uncle Andrew than anything that had happened yet.
Such a horrid( 恐怖的 ), bloodthirsty( 嗜血的 ) din( 喧闹声 ) of hungry and angry brutes( 野兽 ) he had never heard in his life.
Then, to his utter( 完全的 ) rage( 愤怒 ) and horror( 恐惧 ), he saw the other three humans actually walking out into the open to meet the animals.
“The fools!” he said to himself. “Now those brutes( 野兽 ) will eat the rings along with the children and I’ll never be able to get home again.
What a selfish little boy that Digory is! And the others are just as bad.
If they want to throw away their own lives, that’s their business.
But what about me? They don’t seem to think of that. No one thinks of me.”
Finally, when a whole crowd of animals came rushing toward him, he turned and ran for his life.
And now anyone could see that the air of that young world was really doing the old gentleman good.
In London he had been far too old to run: now, he ran at a speed which would have made him certain to win the hundred yards’ race at any Prep school in England.
His coat-tails flying out behind him were a fine sight.
But of course it was no use. Many of the animals behind him were swift( 跑得快的 ) ones;
it was the first run they had ever taken in their lives and they were all longing to use their new muscles( 肌肉 ).
“After him! After him!” they shouted. “Perhaps he’s that Neevil! Tally-ho! Tantivy( 快跑 )! Cut him off! Round him up! Keep it up! Hurrah( 好哇，表欢呼 )!”
In a very few minutes some of them got ahead of him.
They lined up in a row and barred his way.
Others hemmed him in( 把他围住 ) from behind. Wherever he looked he saw terrors.
Antlers( 鹿角 ) of great elks( 麋鹿 ) and the huge face of an elephant towered over( 高出很多 ) him.
Heavy, serious-minded bears and boars( 野猪 ) grunted( 发出呼噜声 ) behind him.
Cool-looking leopards( 美洲豹 ) and panthers( 黑豹 ) with sarcastic( 讥讽的 ) faces (as he thought) stared at him and waved their tails.
What struck him most of all was the number of open mouths. The animals had really opened their mouths to pant( 喘息 ); he thought they had opened their mouths to eat him.
Uncle Andrew stood trembling( 颤抖的 ) and swaying this way and that( 东摇西摆 ).
He had never liked animals at the best of times, being usually rather afraid of them;
and of course years of doing cruel experiments on animals had made him hate and fear them far more.
“Now, sir,” said the Bulldog( 斗牛犬 ) in his business-like way, “are you animal, vegetable, or mineral?” That was what it really said; but all Uncle Andrew heard was “Gr-r-r-arrh-ow!”
You may think the animals were very stupid not to see at once that Uncle Andrew was the same kind of creature as the two children and the Cabby( 马车夫 ).
But you must remember that the animals knew nothing about clothes.
They thought that Polly’s frock( 连衣裙 ) and Digory’s Norfolk suit and the Cabby( 马车夫 )’s bowler hat were as much parts of them as their own fur and feathers.
They wouldn’t have known even that those three were all of the same kind if they hadn’t spoken to them and if Strawberry had not seemed to think so.
And Uncle Andrew was a great deal taller than the children and a good deal thinner than the Cabby( 马车夫 ).
He was all in black except for his white waistcoat( 西服背心 ) (not very white by now),
and the great gray mop of his hair( 乱蓬蓬的头发 ) (now very wild indeed) didn’t look to them like anything they had seen in the three other humans.
So it was only natural that they should be puzzled( 困惑的 ). Worst of all, he didn’t seem to be able to talk.

He had tried to. When the Bulldog( 斗牛犬 ) spoke to him (or, as he thought, first snarled( 低吼 ) and then growled( 咆哮 ) at him) he held out his shaking hand and gasped( 气喘吁吁地说 ) “Good Doggie, then, poor old fellow.”
But the beasts could not understand him any more than he could understand them.
They didn’t hear any words: only a vague( 模糊的 ) sizzling( 咝咝作响的 ) noise.
Perhaps it was just as well they didn’t, for no dog that I ever knew, least of all a Talking Dog of Narnia, likes being called a Good Doggie then;
any more than you would like being called My Little Man.
Then Uncle Andrew dropped down( 倒下 ) in a dead faint( 昏厥 ).
“There!” said a Warthog( 疣猪 ), “it’s only a tree. I always thought so.” (Remember, they had never yet seen a faint( 昏厥 ) or even a fall.)
The Bulldog( 斗牛犬 ), who had been sniffing( 嗅 ) Uncle Andrew all over, raised its head and said, “It’s an animal. Certainly an animal. And probably the same kind as those other ones.”
“I don’t see that,” said one of the Bears. “An animal wouldn’t just roll over( 翻倒 ) like that.
We’re animals and we don’t roll over( 翻倒 ). We stand up. Like this.”
He rose to his hind legs( 后腿 ), took a step backward( 向后地 ), tripped over a low branch and fell flat on his back.
“The Third Joke, the Third Joke, the Third Joke!” said the Jackdaw( 寒鸦 ) in great excitement.
“I still think it’s a sort of tree,” said the Warthog( 疣猪 ).
“If it’s a tree,” said the other Bear, “there might be a bees’ nest in it.”
“I’m sure it’s not a tree,” said the Badger( 獾 ). “I had a sort of idea it was trying to speak before it toppled( 倒下 ) over.”
“That was only the wind in its branches,” said the Warthog( 疣猪 ).
“You surely don’t mean,” said the Jackdaw( 寒鸦 ) to the Badger( 獾 ), “that you think it’s a talking animal! It didn’t say any words.”
“And yet, you know,” said the Elephant (the She-Elephant, of course; her husband, as you remember, had been called away by Aslan).
“And yet, you know, it might be an animal of some kind.
Mightn’t the whitish lump( 块 ) at this end be a sort of face?
And couldn’t those holes be eyes and a mouth?
No nose, of course. But then—ahem( 嗯哼 )—one mustn’t be narrow-minded.
Very few of us have what could exactly be called a Nose.”
She squinted( 斜眼看 ) down the length of her own trunk with pardonable pride.
“I object to that remark very strongly,” said the Bulldog( 斗牛犬 ).
“The Elephant is quite right,” said the Tapir( 貘 ).
“I tell you what!” said the Donkey( 驴子 ) brightly, “perhaps it’s an animal that can’t talk but thinks it can.”
“Can it be made to stand up?” said the Elephant thoughtfully.

She took the limp( 软弱无力的 ) form of Uncle Andrew gently in her trunk and set him up on end: upside down, unfortunately, so that two half-sovereigns( 金镑 ), three half-crowns( 克朗，钱币 ), and a sixpence( 六便士硬币 ) fell out of his pocket.
But it was no use. Uncle Andrew merely collapsed( 倒下 ) again.
“There!” said several voices. “It isn’t an animal at all. It’s not alive.”
“I tell you, it is an animal,” said the Bulldog( 斗牛犬 ). “Smell it for yourself.”
“Smelling isn’t everything,” said the Elephant.
“Why,” said the Bulldog( 斗牛犬 ), “if a fellow can’t trust his nose, what is he to trust?”
“Well, his brains, perhaps,” she replied mildly.
“I object to that remark very strongly,” said the Bulldog( 斗牛犬 ).
“Well, we must do something about it,” said the Elephant. “Because it may be the Neevil, and it must be shown to Aslan. What do most of us think? Is it an animal or something of the tree kind?”
“Tree! Tree!” said a dozen voices.
“Very well,” said the Elephant. “Then, if it’s a tree it wants to be planted. We must dig a hole.”

article_info.previous: 狮子Aslan向大家宣布，纳尼亚王国成立了。Digory希望和Aslan对话，也许它可以治好自己的母亲。但Uncle Andrew对于刚刚发生的这一切，和众人有着不同的看法。

article_info.share_words: He was all in black except for his white waistcoat (not very white by now), and the great gray mop of his hair(not very wild indeed) didn’t look to them like anything they had seen in the three other human.

question.cn: Uncle Andrew错过了什么伟大的时刻？
question.en: What great moment did Uncle Andrew miss?

analysis: 文中提到：“When the great moment came and the Beasts spoke, he missed the whole point; for a rather interesting reason.”由此可知，Uncle Andrew错过的伟大时刻是动物们开口讲话，因此选A。

question.cn: 当Uncle Andrew看见Digory走向动物时，是什么感受？
question.en: How did Uncle Andrew feel when he saw Digory going to the animals?

analysis: 文中提到：“Then, to his utter rage and horror, he saw the other three humans actually walking into the open to meet the animals.”由此可知，当Uncle Andrew看见Digory一行人走向动物群时，他是十分生气的，因此选A。

question.cn: 当动物向Uncle Andrew冲来时，他做了什么？
question.en: What did Uncle Andrew do when the animals rushed towards him?

options.en: He turned and ran for his life.

analysis: 文中提到：“Finally, when a whole crowd of animals rushing toward him, he turned and ran for his life.”由此可知，当Uncle Andrew发现一大群动物朝他奔来时，他选择转身逃命，因此选B。

question.cn: 为什么Uncle Andrew讨厌和害怕动物？
question.en: Why did Uncle Andrew hate and fear animals?

options.cn: 因为他认为它们又丑又脏。
options.en: Because he thought they were ugly and dirty.

options.cn: 因为他多年来在动物身上做残酷的实验。
options.en: Because he did cruel experiments on animals for years.

options.cn: 因为他看见的大多数动物都很大。
options.en: Because most animals he saw were very big.

analysis: 文中提到Uncle Andrew不喜欢动物，再加上“Years of doing cruel experiments on animals had made him hate and fear them far more.”由此可知多年来在动物身上做实验也使得Uncle Andrew讨厌和害怕动物，因此选B。

question.cn: 大多数动物认为Uncle Andrew是什么？
question.en: What did most of animals think of Uncle Andrew?

options.cn: 他们觉得他是一种动物。
options.en: They thought he was an animal.
They thought he was a bird.
They thought he was a tree.

analysis: 文中提到：“What do most of us think? Is it an animal or something of the tree kind?” “Tree! Tree!” said a dozen voices.”由此可知大多数的动物都认为Uncle Andrew是一棵树，因此选C。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第35天
